skill: Student can place two same-denominator fractions on stacked number lines and select the correct comparison symbol
problem_type: Student places a point on each of two stacked number lines (one fraction each), then selects the correct symbol to compare them
workspace_description: Three sequential workspaces. Step 1: Two number lines visible, both 0–1 range, same denominator tick marks, labeled 0 and 1. Top line is active (student places point). Bottom line is read-only reference with no point yet. Step 2: Top line is now read-only showing placed point from Step 1. Bottom line becomes active (student places point). Step 3: Both lines read-only with points placed. MathExpression shows fraction pair with symbol placeholder. Three symbol choices: <, =, >.
prompt_examples: Place each fraction on its number line. Then select the correct symbol.
Mark both fractions on the lines. Which symbol compares them correctly?
Place the points, then choose the symbol that compares the fractions.
action_description: Step 1: Student clicks a tick mark on the top number line to place a point. Step 2: Student clicks a tick mark on the bottom number line to place a point. Step 3: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices.
correct_end_state: Both points placed correctly and correct comparison symbol selected
success_dialogue: Right. The fraction farther to the right is greater.
Correct. You counted the intervals and chose the right symbol.
Yes. Same denominator means you compare how many intervals.
That's it. Both are sixths, so you can count to compare.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-denominator fractions already placed on stacked number lines
problem_type: Student views two fractions already marked on stacked number lines and selects the correct symbol
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines, both 0–1 range, same denominator tick marks, labeled 0 and 1. Points already placed on each line. MathExpression shows 'a/b ? c/b'. Three symbol choices: <, =, >.
prompt_examples: Look at the two points. Select the correct symbol to compare these fractions.
The fractions are already placed. Which symbol is correct?
Which symbol correctly compares the two fractions shown?
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
success_dialogue: Right. The point farther to the right shows the greater fraction.
Correct. That symbol matches what you see on the lines.
Yes. Same-size intervals, so the one with more is greater.
That's it. The symbol matches which point is farther right.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-denominator fractions using only notation
problem_type: Student selects the correct symbol to compare two same-denominator fractions shown only as notation
workspace_description: MathExpression shows two fractions with the same denominator and a symbol placeholder. Three symbol choices: <, =, >. No bars or number lines visible.
prompt_examples: Select the correct symbol. No visual this time.
Which symbol compares these fractions correctly?
Both fractions have the same denominator. Which symbol goes between them?
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
success_dialogue: Right. Same denominator means you compare the numerators.
Correct. That's the right symbol.
Yes. You compared the numerators and chose correctly.
That's it. Both are eighths, so 3 versus 5.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for unit fractions by comparing piece sizes shown in bars
problem_type: Student views two bars each with one piece shaded (numerator = 1, different denominators) and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: Two rectangle bars, both same total size, each with one piece shaded (unit fraction). Different denominators create visibly different piece sizes. Three text choices: 'a/b is greater than c/d', 'a/b is equal to c/d', 'a/b is less than c/d'.
prompt_examples: Both bars have one piece shaded. Which piece is bigger? Select the correct statement.
Look at the shaded pieces. Select the statement that compares these fractions.
Both show one piece. Which fraction is greater? Choose the correct statement.
action_description: Student clicks one of three statements — 'a/b is greater than c/d', 'a/b is equal to c/d', or 'a/b is less than c/d'
correct_end_state: Correct statement selected — smaller denominator means bigger piece, so smaller denominator fraction is always greater
success_dialogue: Right. Fewer parts means bigger pieces.
Correct. One fourth is a bigger piece than one eighth.
Yes. The smaller denominator gives bigger pieces.
That's it. Cutting into fewer parts creates bigger slices.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator non-unit fractions by comparing piece sizes in bars
problem_type: Student views two bars with the same number of pieces shaded (numerator > 1, different denominators) and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: Two rectangle bars, both same total size, with the same number of pieces shaded but different denominators, creating visibly different piece sizes. No labels on bars. Three MCQ options show the full comparison expression.
prompt_examples: Both bars show the same number of pieces shaded. Which pieces are bigger? Select the correct symbol.
Same number of pieces, but are they the same size? Select the symbol.
Which fraction is greater? Look at the size of the pieces.
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
correct_end_state: Correct symbol selected — smaller denominator means bigger pieces, so the fraction with the smaller denominator is greater
success_dialogue: Right. Same count, but bigger pieces win.
Correct. Fifths are bigger pieces than sevenths.
Yes. Fewer parts in the whole means bigger pieces.
That's it. Three-fourths beats three-eighths.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator fractions by comparing interval sizes on stacked number lines
problem_type: Student views two stacked number lines with points at the same numerator position (different denominators) and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines, both 0–1 range, different denominators, labeled 0 and 1. Points pre-placed at the same numerator position on each line. MathExpression shows the fraction pair with a symbol placeholder. Three symbol choices: <, =, >.
prompt_examples: Both points are the same number of intervals from zero. Which intervals are bigger? Select the correct symbol.
Same number of steps from zero, but different-sized steps. Which fraction is greater?
Look at where the two points are. Select the symbol to compare these fractions.
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
correct_end_state: Correct symbol selected (fraction with smaller denominator is greater)
success_dialogue: Right. Same number of intervals, but thirds are bigger intervals than sixths.
Correct. The bigger intervals make the bigger fraction.
Yes. Fewer divisions means bigger intervals.
That's it. Two-thirds is greater than two-sixths.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator fractions on stacked number lines with harder denominator pairs
problem_type: Student views two stacked number lines with points at the same numerator position (harder pairs) and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines, both 0–1 range, labeled 0 and 1. Larger or closer denominators make interval size difference less obvious. Points pre-placed. MathExpression shows the fraction pair with a symbol placeholder. Three symbol choices: <, =, >.
prompt_examples: Both fractions have the same numerator. Which intervals are bigger? Select the symbol.
Look at the interval sizes on each line. Which symbol is correct?
Same numerator, different denominators. Which fraction is greater?
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
success_dialogue: Right. Fifths are bigger than eighths.
Correct. Smaller denominator, bigger piece.
Yes. Fewer divisions means bigger intervals.
That's it. The fraction with the smaller denominator is greater.

skill: Student can identify that a same-denominator pair requires the same-denominator strategy
problem_type: Student views a fraction pair with the same denominator and selects two correct answers from four strategy options
workspace_description: Two bars and a MathExpression showing the fraction pair. Four multiple choice options shown. Student must select exactly two correct options.
prompt_examples: Which TWO can help you compare these fractions?
How would you compare these fractions? Select TWO options.
Which TWO steps of the strategy apply here?
action_description: Student selects two options from four choices (allow_multiple: true)
correct_end_state: Both correct options selected (same-denominator + count parts)
success_dialogue: Right. Same denominator means you count the parts.
Correct. Both are sevenths, so you compare how many.
Yes. You identified the right strategy.
That's it. Same denominator, count the intervals.

skill: Student can identify that a same-numerator pair requires the same-numerator strategy
problem_type: Student views a fraction pair with the same numerator and selects two correct answers from four strategy options
workspace_description: Two bars and a MathExpression showing the fraction pair. Four multiple choice options shown. Student must select exactly two correct options.
prompt_examples: Which TWO can help you compare these fractions?
How would you compare these fractions? Select TWO options.
Which TWO steps of the strategy apply here?
action_description: Student selects two options from four choices (allow_multiple: true)
correct_end_state: Both correct options selected (same-numerator + compare piece sizes)
success_dialogue: Right. Same numerator means you compare piece sizes.
Correct. Both show three pieces, so you check which pieces are bigger.
Yes. You spotted the matching numerators.
That's it. Same numerator, compare the sizes.

skill: Student can select the explanation that correctly describes why a same-numerator comparison is true
problem_type: Student views a same-numerator comparison statement and selects the best explanation from three choices
workspace_description: Two bars showing the fraction pair for reference. Four explanation choices, one correct.
prompt_examples: Which statement explains why 3/5 > 3/7?
Why is three-fifths greater than three-sevenths?
Select the statement that explains why 3/5 > 3/7.
action_description: Student clicks one explanation from four choices

mcq_options: Both show 3 parts, but fifths are bigger than sevenths.
7 > 5 and both show 3 parts, which makes 3/7 larger.
3 is smaller than both 5 and 7, so 3/5 is biggest.
Both show 3 parts, so 3/5 is equal to 3/7.

success_dialogue: Right. Same count, but bigger pieces.
Correct. Fewer parts means each piece is larger.
Yes. That's the right explanation.
That's it. Fifths are bigger pieces than sevenths.

skill: Student can identify which unit fraction represents a bigger piece when shown two differently-divided bars
problem_type: Student views two bars each showing one equal part (different denominators) and selects which shows the bigger piece
workspace_description: Two rectangle bars, both same total size, each showing one equal part highlighted. Different denominators create visibly different piece sizes. Student clicks one bar to select it.
prompt_examples: Which bar shows a bigger piece?
One bar is cut into fewer parts. Which piece is bigger?
Click the bar that shows the larger piece.
action_description: Student clicks one bar to select it
correct_end_state: Bar with smaller denominator (bigger piece) selected
success_dialogue: Right. Fewer parts means each piece is bigger.
Correct. That bar has bigger pieces.
Yes. Cutting into 4 parts gives bigger pieces than 8 parts.
That's it. The bar with fewer parts has the bigger pieces.

skill: Student can identify which denominator from a set produces the largest equal pieces
problem_type: Student selects which denominator from three options would give the biggest equal pieces if a bar were divided that many ways
workspace_description: Three denominators shown as options with reference bars showing equal parts (no shading). Student selects one denominator.
prompt_examples: Which denominator gives the biggest pieces?
If you cut a bar into these many equal parts, which gives the biggest piece?
Select the denominator that creates the largest equal pieces.
action_description: Student clicks one denominator from three options
success_dialogue: Right. Fewer parts means bigger pieces.
Correct. Dividing into 3 gives bigger pieces than 6 or 9.
Yes. The smallest number of parts gives the biggest pieces.
That's it. Fewer equal parts means each part is larger.

skill: Student can independently identify the correct comparison strategy and apply it to compare a fraction pair with visual support
problem_type: Student views a fraction pair (same-denom or same-numer) with visual support and selects the correct symbol without a prior strategy prompt
workspace_description: Two bars and a MathExpression showing the fraction pair with a symbol placeholder. May be a same-denom or same-numer pair — no hint given as to which. Three symbol choices: <, =, >.
prompt_examples: Select the correct symbol to compare these fractions.
Which symbol goes between these fractions?
Compare these fractions. Select the correct symbol.
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
correct_end_state: Correct symbol selected using appropriate strategy
success_dialogue: Right. You chose the right strategy and compared correctly.
Correct. You spotted what matched and used the right rule.
Yes. You identified what matched and used the right approach.
That's it. Same denominator means count parts; same numerator means compare piece sizes.

skill: Student can compare same-numerator fractions using notation only, applying piece-size reasoning without visual support
problem_type: Student views a same-numerator fraction pair shown only as notation and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: MathExpression shows two fractions sharing the same numerator with a symbol placeholder. Three symbol choices: <, =, >. No bars or number lines visible.
prompt_examples: Compare these fractions and select the correct symbol.
Which symbol compares these fractions? Think about piece sizes.
Both fractions have the same numerator. Which is greater?
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
correct_end_state: Correct symbol selected (fraction with smaller denominator is greater)
success_dialogue: Right. Smaller denominator means bigger pieces.
Correct. You compared piece sizes without the visual.
Yes. Same numerator means the smaller denominator wins.
That's it. Fewer parts means bigger pieces.

skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator fractions shown only as notation with harder denominator pairs
problem_type: Student views a same-numerator fraction pair with harder denominators shown only as notation and selects the correct comparison symbol
workspace_description: MathExpression shows two fractions sharing the same numerator with a symbol placeholder. Larger denominators (7+) make piece-size difference less obvious. Three symbol choices: <, =, >. No bars or number lines visible.
prompt_examples: Which symbol compares these fractions? No visual — use what you know.
Same numerator. Which fraction is greater? Select the symbol.
Select the correct symbol. Think about the piece sizes.
action_description: Student clicks one symbol (<, =, >) from three choices
correct_end_state: Correct symbol selected (fraction with smaller denominator is greater)
success_dialogue: Right. Smaller denominator means bigger pieces, even without a visual.
Correct. Smaller denominator, bigger piece.
Yes. You compared piece sizes without the visual.
That's right. Fewer equal parts means each part is larger.

skill: Student can order unit fractions by reasoning about piece size with no visual support
problem_type: Student selects the correct ordering of three unit fractions from multiple choice options
workspace_description: MathExpression showing three unit fractions. Multiple choice with three ordering options. No bars or number lines visible.
prompt_examples: Which option shows these fractions in order from smallest to largest?
Which option shows these fractions in order from largest to smallest?
Put these fractions in order. Select the correct option.
action_description: Student clicks one ordering sequence from three options
correct_end_state: Correct ordering sequence selected — smaller denominator = larger unit fraction
success_dialogue: Right. Smaller denominator means bigger piece.
Correct. Smaller denominator means bigger piece, so the order flips from what you might expect.
Yes. Fewer parts means each piece is larger.
That's it. The smallest denominator makes the biggest piece.
